answers.answer: Well, there are chances, sharing the same needle can help HIV to transmit to others... The blood that is filled inside the needle is protected from air thus HIV remains live... Entering the same needle in to another body have a high risk of transmission... To clear up all your confusions, you should test at 12 weeks which would be conclusive... In the meanwhile, please relax, as its just a doubt, you are not even sure if someone who used the needle had HIV...
The diabetes tester's needle is not hollow.Could this effect your answer?
You didn't have a risk sharing a lancet.

oops sorry, i didn't focus on that i just read the word needle... While it is possible, I don't think it's too common ... so i wouldn't worry too much about that... If you think you have been exposed to any blood borne diseases, get tested

question: Once, I used the diabetes tester with a couple of people.I was the one who used it at last.We shared the same needle.If one of those people have HIV, can I catch HIV from that needle?Please answer my question.I'm worried too much.Thanks alot.
title: sharing diabetes tester
